Clinical Data Flow Process

  • Protocol
  • CRF
  • Tools
  • Data Sources
  • Database Lock
  • SAP
  • Reporting
  • Publication
  • Protocol: Master document (objectives, methodology).
  • Case Report Form: Data collection tool (paper or electronic).
  • EDC: Electronic data capture
  • Examples: Medidata Rave, Oracle Clinical One, IBM Clinical Development
  • Labs, EHRs (Electronic Health Records), wearables.
  • Freezing data: Interim (partial), Soft (review), Final (lock)
  • Stages: Screening ‚Üí Baseline ‚Üí Treatment ‚Üí Follow-up
  • Statistical Analysis Plan: defines how, when, and on which data, statistical analyses will be performed
  • Reporting in form of TFLs (Tables, Listings, Figures).
  • Final CSR (Clinical Study Report) shared to regulatory.
  • Share findings with the world via journals/conferences

Need of standards in clinical research

  • Scenario
  • Problem
  • Solution

Imagine a global trial running in Nepal, the US, and Japan.

  • In Nepal, a doctor writes ‚ÄúBP: 120/80‚Äù.

  • In the US, a coordinator enters ‚ÄúBlood Pressure: 120/80‚Äù.

  • In Japan, the data is exported as ‚ÄúKetsuatsu: 120/80.‚Äù

üö´ Problem: Different people call the same thing different names.

Example:

  • BP
  • Blood Pressure
  • Ketsuatsu

‚úÖ Solution: Standards provide a common dictionary.

Example:

  • SYSBP (Systolic Blood Pressure) <- 120

  • DIABP (Diastolic Blood Pressure) <- 80

The ‚ÄúBig Picture‚Äù Analogy

  • About
  • In clinical world

Think of a clinical trial like building a house.

  • Collecting Bricks & Wood: Raw datasets (lab, vital sign)
  • Following the Blueprint: Standards (CDASH, SDTM, ADaM)
  • Building the House: Analysis Datasets
  • Moving In: Final Reports (TLFs, CSR)
  • CDASH is the shopping list for materials.
  • SDTM is the blueprint for the frame.
  • ADaM is the interior design for analysis.
  • TLF & CSR is the final report (the results).

What is CDASH?

  • About
  • Example

CDASH stands for Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization.

  • What it is: A standard published by CDISC (Clinical Data Interchange Standards Consortium) on how to collect data from the patient or investigator.

  • The Goal: To ensure that the data collected in the Case Report Forms (CRFs) is consistent across different sites, studies, and companies.

Example: Collecting Date of Birth

  • Without CDASH: DOB, BIRTH_DT, PAT_BIRTH, DateOfBirth

  • With CDASH: The field is standardized as BRTHDAT (standard variable name) with a specific format (e.g., YYYY-MM-DD).

Key Point: ‚ÄúCollect data once, use it many times.‚Äù

What is SDTM?

  • About
  • Components
  • Raw Data
  • SDTM data

SDTM stands for Study Data Tabulation Model.

  • What it is: A standard for organizing and formatting the collected data (from CDASH) into a machine-readable format. This is the data you submit to the FDA.

  • The Goal: To create a standardized database structure so regulators can easily review and understand the data, regardless of who submitted it.

Key SDTM Classes (Domains):

  • Interventions: Treatments given (e.g., CM - Concomitant Medications).

  • Events: Things that happen (e.g., AE - Adverse Events).

  • Findings: Observations/measurements (e.g., LB - Laboratory Tests, VS - Vital Signs).

  • Demographics: (e.g., DM - Demographics)

Structure: SDTM uses a standard ‚Äú2-letter domain code‚Äù and a standard set of variables for every row (e.g., --TEST, --ORRES, --STRESC).

What is ADaM?

  • About
  • Principles
  • Data

ADaM stands for Analysis Data Model.

  • What it is: A standard for creating datasets that are specifically designed for statistical analysis.

  • The Goal: To make the analysis process transparent and traceable. You should be able to trace a number in a final report all the way back to a specific row in an SDTM dataset.

Key Principles:

  1. Analysis-Ready: A statistician can use this data with minimal programming.

  2. Traceability: Clear links back to the source SDTM data.

  3. Metadata: Clear documentation of how derived variables (like ‚Äúchange from baseline‚Äù) were calculated.

Example: ADaM dataset ADVS (Analysis Dataset Vital Signs) will contain a row for each patient and visit, with variables like CHG (Change from Baseline) already calculated.

What are TLFs?

  • About
  • Summary
  • Mockshells
  • Tables

TLF stands for Tables, Listings, and Figures.

  • What it is: The final output of the statistical analysis. This is what goes into the Clinical Study Report (CSR).

  • The Goal: To present the results of the clinical trial in a clear, interpretable format for clinicians, regulators, and the public.

Breaking it down:

  • Tables: Summary of data (e.g., ‚ÄúTable 14-1.1: Summary of Adverse Events by Treatment Group‚Äù).

  • Listings: Line-by-line data of individual patients (e.g., ‚ÄúListing 16-2.1: Listing of Patients Who Died‚Äù).

  • Figures: Graphical representations (e.g., ‚ÄúFigure 14-3.1: Kaplan-Meier Plot of Overall Survival‚Äù).

The Full Data Flow

1. PATIENT VISIT
   |
   |  (Data is entered into a CRF following CDASH standards)
   v
2. RAW DATA (CDASH)
   |
   |  (Data is cleaned, transformed, and structured)
   v
3. SUBMISSION DATA (SDTM) --> Submitted to FDA
   |
   |  (Data is further derived and aggregated for analysis)
   v
4. ANALYSIS DATA (ADaM)
   |
   |  (Statistical programs are run)
   v
5. RESULTS (TLF) --> Goes into Clinical Study Report

What You‚Äôve Learned Today

  1. CDASH: Standardizes data collection. (The ‚ÄúHow‚Äù we ask).

  2. SDTM: Standardizes data tabulation. (The ‚ÄúWhat‚Äù we submit).

  3. ADaM: Standardizes analysis datasets. (The ‚ÄúHow‚Äù we analyze).

  4. TLF: Standardizes results presentation. (The ‚ÄúWhat‚Äù we conclude).

Why should a you care?
Because you are the bridge between the clinic (data collection) and the boardroom (results). Understanding these standards makes you an invaluable asset to any clinical research or pharmaceutical company.

QUIZ TIME!

  • Part 1
  • Part 2

Q1. If you are designing a Case Report Form (CRF) for a new study, which standard should you follow?
a) SDTM
b) ADaM
c) CDASH
d) TLF

Q2. Which dataset model is the primary one submitted to regulatory authorities like the FDA?
a) CDASH
b) SDTM
c) ADaM
d) TLF

Q3. A statistician needs to create a Kaplan-Meier survival plot. From which dataset will they primarily derive the analysis?
a) Raw CDASH data
b) SDTM datasets
c) ADaM datasets
d) The Case Report Form

Q4. What does ‚ÄòTLF‚Äô stand for?
a) Technical Layout Function
b) Tables, Listings, and Figures
c) Trial Level Finalization
d) Top-Level Format

Quiz Answers

A1. c) CDASH
(CDASH is specifically for data acquisition/collection.)

A2. b) SDTM
(SDTM is the standard for data tabulation submitted to the FDA.)

A3. c) ADaM
(ADaM is analysis-ready data, designed specifically for generating statistics and TLFs.)

A4. b) Tables, Listings, and Figures
(This is the final output of the analysis.)
